Graphical abstract A Co/CeO2 Mott-Schottky heterojunction embedded in N-doped carbon nanoboxes is synthesized through a simple MOF-assisted etching-pyrolysis strategy. The Co–O–Ce bond bridge formed at the heterojunction interface effectively facilitates electron transfer, modulates the local electronic configuration, and optimizes the adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates at the active site, thereby offering excellent electrocatalytic bifunctionality for both ORR and OER. Designing a heterogeneous interface to improve the kinetics of electrocatalysts represents an effective yet challenging approach for enhancing the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, a simple MOF-assisted etching-pyrolysis strategy is proposed to fabricate an advanced Mott-Schottky (M-S) electrocatalyst composed of Co/CeO2 hetero-nanoparticles embedded within N-doped hollow carbon nanoboxes (H-Co/CeO2@NCBs). Notably, the interfacial Co–O–Ce bond bridging productively facilitates the electron transfer and modulates the charge distribution of the active center, thereby contributing to the ORR/OER kinetics. As expected, the optimal M-S H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst exhibits promising bifunctional electrocatalytic activity with a small potential discrepancy of 0.65 V. Theoretical calculations reveal that the built-in electric field in the M-S heterojunction promotes electron transfer in oxygen electrocatalysis and the interfacial bridge-induced electron redistribution optimizes the adsorption/desorption of the oxygen intermediates, leading to reduced activation energy for the bifunctional ORR/OER reactions. Importantly, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-assembled Zn-air battery (ZAB) delivers high power density (179.8 mW cm−2) and long-term stability (400 h). Furthermore, the assembled flexible solid-state ZAB with H-Co/CeO2@NCBs cathode also exhibits excellent charge-discharge reversibility and flexibility at various bending angles. This work provides a novel perspective on developing efficient and stable M-S bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Keywords Mott-schottky effect Built-in electric field Co–O–Ce bridge Bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis Flexible zinc-air battery 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for clean energy, regenerative energy storage and conversion devices have been triggered significant interest to address this energy issue in the 21st century [1,2]. Recently, rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) has been deemed as a promising device in the field of energy storage and conversion on account of its safety, high energy density environmental friendliness [3,4]. Whereas, the sluggish of ORR and OER in terms of dynamics has seriously hindered the commercialization of rechargeable ZAB [5,6]. Currently, the noble metal based electrocatalysts (Pt, RuO2) are considered as the advanced oxygen electrocatalysts. However, their high cost and poor durability restrict their widespread application [7,8]. Therefore, it is of great significance to seek bifunctional electrocatalysts with high ORR/OER activity [9,10]. Recently, transition metal cobalt (Co)-based catalysts, such as elemental Co, Co3O4, and Co single-atom catalysts, have gained attention as promising bifunctional alternatives to precious metal-based electrocatalysts due to highly-efficient catalytic sites, versatile redox chemistry and the easily adjustable electronic configurations of their 3d orbitals [11–15]. Although a lot of efforts have been done to heighten catalytic performance of Co-based materials, the overall catalytic performance of ORR and OER is still unsatisfactory due to their poor electrical conductivity and limited accessibility to active sites [16,17]. To address these issues, many effective strategies have been developed, including multi-metal alloying, heterogeneous interface engineering, and nanocarbon hybridization, etc., primarily aiming to optimize the electrocatalytic performance of Co species from the perspectives of electronic modulation and nano-architectonics design [18–20]. Among various electronic modification strategies, manipulating heterojunctions between different functional components can expeditiously induce electronic reconfiguration in adjacent regions, adjust the electronic state of active sites, and accelerate the charge transfer rate, thereby causing a significant enhancement of intrinsic activity [21–23]. Particularly, manipulating heterojunctions between metals and semiconductors with different Fermi energy levels at the nanoscale, such as Mott-Schottky (M-S) type heterostructures, can spontaneously drive electron flow through metal/semiconductor interfaces until thermodynamic equilibrium state is reached, generating a stable built-in electric field [24–27]. Electronic reconstruction configuration may significantly heighten charge transport and adjust the chemisorption free energy of the reaction intermediates, resulting in reactivity and selectivity significantly superior to that of the physical mixtures or single-component counterparts [28–31]. Importantly, in an M-S heterojunction, electron- and hole-concentrated areas are concurrently formed, which can improve the dynamics of the ORR gained by electrons and the OER lost by electrons [32]. However, current reports on Co-based M-S electrocatalysts often involve complicated and cumbersome synthesis methods, and the intrinsic mechanisms behind the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of these M-S heterojunctions remain largely unexplored [32,33]. Therefore, the meticulous design of Co-based M-S heterostructures presents a prospective and feasible option to attaining high-efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis [34,35]. In addition to modulating the chemical composition, the geometric structure of catalysts plays a crucial role in determining the electrocatalytic activity [36,37]. Hollow nanostructures have shown extensive applications in gas capture, energy storage, and catalysis owing to their advantageous features, including high surface area-to-volume ratios, well-defined internal spaces, and minimized mass/charge transfer distances [38,39]. Specifically, hollow nanostructures offer unique advantages in promoting electrochemical reactions, including abundant exposed active sites and large contact areas between catalyst and electrolyte, compared with ordinary nanostructured materials [40,41]. For instance, Feng et al. fabricate cactus-like NiCo2S4@NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) hollow spheres via a simple hydrothermal method [42]. This unique hollow structure can effectively guarantee the flow-pattern uniformity and shorten the cavity/pore-scale mass transfer distance, thereby promoting significant bifunctional electrocatalytic efficiencies for both ORR and OER. Additionally, Peng et al. prepared NiFe-LDH/Fe1-N-C heterostructure hollow nanorods, which exhibit prominent bifunctional catalytic activities for OER and ORR due to increased electrolyte-interface area, facilitating efficient oxygen adsorption and desorption [43]. Therefore, hollow nanostructured materials have emerged as a research hotspot in the field of electrocatalysis. Inspired by the aforementioned considerations, we herein present an advanced M-S electrocatalyst composed of Co/CeO2 hetero-nanoparticles embedded within N-doped hollow carbon nanoboxes (designated as H-Co/CeO2@NCBs) through an uncomplicated MOF-assisted etching-pyrolysis strategy. Cerium oxide (CeO2), with its remarkable oxygen-storage capacity, reversible conversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+, outstanding ionic conductivity, and abundant oxygen vacancies, should act as a promising auxiliary promoter in oxygen electrocatalysis. The highly open hollow structure can provide the pathways and three-phase interfaces for mass/electron transfer and reactions, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics. Experimental results and theoretical calculations reveal that formative Co–O–Ce bridge greatly strengthen interfacial interactions and the flow of electrons via O atoms from Co to Ce, modulating the charge distribution at the active center and consequently facilitating the ORR/OER process. In particular, causing the reduction of the d-band center and adjusting the electronic state delocalization of the active center via the Co–O–Ce bridge can enhance the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates, lowering the energy barrier for ORR/OER process. Notably, the bifunctional H-Co/CeO2@NCBs electrocatalyst exhibits an outstanding performance in rechargeable ZABs, achieving high power-density of 179.8 mW cm−2 while maintaining long-term stability for over 400 h. Besides, the flexible ZAB with the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs as the cathode catalyst demonstrates exceptional energy efficiency, flexibility and cycling stability under different bending conditions. This work provides a fresh insight to develop highly efficient M-S catalysts for oxygen electrocatalysis, ZABs and flexible ZABs. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Theoretical study of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs M-S heterojunctions The intelligent design of the M-S interface can generate natural electron flow, greatly enhancing the charge transfer efficiency. DFT calculations are first conducted to investigate the electronic and transfer properties of Co/CeO2 heterojunctions. The theoretical models of Co, CeO2 and Co/CeO2 are constructed for analysis in Fig. 1a . The work functions of Co and CeO2 are 4.87 and 5.45 eV, respectively, meeting the necessary condition for forming a Schottky barrier (Fig. 1b–d). When Co is brought into direct interaction with CeO2, electrons will naturally migrate from Co to CeO2 via Co/CeO2 interface until Fermi levels on both sides reach balance (Fig. 1e). This process triggers self-driven electron redistribution, leading to the creation of an ongoing electron circulation and a built-in electric field. Furthermore, the mechanism underlying the excellent catalytic performance of the Co/CeO2 M-S catalyst is further revealed via calculation. The charge density variation of Co/CeO2 is visually depicted in Fig. 1f to clearly understand the effect of Co–O–Ce bridging on the surface electronic states. It is evident that the spontaneous charge flow from Co to Ce atoms originates from the interfacial Co–O–Ce bridges, which enhance ongoing electron transfer between the two phases. Besides, the electronic local function (ELF) plotted in Fig. 1g also confirms the presence of chemical bonds at the Co/CeO2 interface, promoting the redistribution of localized charge. 2.2 Synthesis and structural characterizations A diagram illustrating the fabrication of the hollow heterostructures consisting of Co/CeO2 hetero-nanoparticles embedded in NCBs is presented in Fig. 2a . First, CoCe-ZIF is prepared by combining metal (Co/Ce) salts and dimethylimidazole in an aqueous solution containing cetyltrimethylammonium bromide. Subsequently, CoCe-ZIF is subjected to chemical etching using protons that come from TA, leading to the creation of TA-CoCe-ZIF. Following this etching process, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is synthesized by carbonizing CoCe-ZIF at a temperature of 700 °C in N2 atmosphere. Detailed experimental procedures and characterization techniques are provided in Supporting Information. The structure and morphology of synthesized H-Co/CeO2@NCBs are analyzed by SEM and TEM. Fig. 2b, e demonstrate CoCe-ZIF is successfully prepared with an uniform cubic morphology, with particle sizes of approximately 300 nm. Interestingly, compared with ZIF-67, many nanoparticles are clearly observed on the edges and inside the walls of CoCe-ZIF, with their quantity increasing as Ce content rises, which should be attributed to the introduction of Ce (Fig. 2e; Figs. S1 and S2a). Moreover, EDS mapping images further verify the existence of Ce in CoCe-ZIF (Fig. S3). The TA-CoCe-ZIF remarkably retain their initial cubic morphology and CoCe-ZIF has been successfully transformed into hollow structure through the coordination reaction (Fig. 2c, f). Fig. 2d, g illustrate that the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs still maintains its hollow cubic structure during the pyrolysis process, with surface nanoparticles becoming more pronounced and the surface roughening. However, when the Ce loading increases to approximately 15%, the cubic structure collapses significantly and loses its original shape (Fig. S2b). HRTEM images confirm the presence of heterointerfaces between the Co and CeO2 components in intimate contact, which likely contributes to a synergistic effect, resulting in superior catalytic properties compared to the individual component counterparts (Fig. 2h). The specific interplanar spacings of 0.20 and 0.31 nm correspond to the (111) faces of Co and CeO2, respectively [12,44]. As shown by the solid red line highlighted in Fig. 2h, the interfaces between Co and CeO2 domains are clearly identifiable, thereby confirming the successful creation of M-S heterointerfaces. EDS mapping images in Fig. 2i validate the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O, Co and Ce elements within the synthesized H-Co/CeO2@NCBs. Fig. 3a presents the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the Co phase (JCPDS No. 15-0806) in the Co@NC sample and the CeO2 phase (JCPDS No. 34-0394) in the CeO2@NC sample [12,44]. The H-Co/CeO2@NCBs sample exhibits a combination of Co and CeO2 phases. Compared to H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, the XRD pattern of the contrast sample (Co/CeO2@NC-1) shows no significant differences in Fig. S4. Raman spectroscopy is employed to analyze the chemical composition of carbon (Fig. S5). The high intensity ratios of the D to G peaks (I D/I G = 0.99) in the Raman spectra of the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs suggest the presence of numerous defects on NCBs, which facilitates the exposure of additional catalytic sites for ORR/OER [15]. Besides, N2 adsorption-desorption measurements reveal that the Brunner-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is 297.8 m2 g−1, exceeding both the 174.6 m2 g−1 of CeO2@NC and 229.5 m2 g−1 of Co@NC (Fig. S6). This observation implies that the creation of heterogeneous structures can enhance defect formation and expose more active sites. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to analyze the interfacial structure and electronic properties of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs and comparison samples. The C 1s spectrum displays three peaks at 284.8, 286.3, and 288.7 eV, corresponding to the presence of C–C, C–N and O–C=O bonds, respectively (Fig. S7a) [45]. The N 1s spectrum of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs displays three discernible peaks corresponding to pyridinic N (398.2 eV), pyrrolic N (399.2 eV) and graphitic N (400.6 eV) (Fig. S7b) [41]. The self-doped N is believed to enhance the electron density of the π-conjugated carbon matrix and induce additional defects/vacancies in the original carbon structure, consequently increasing the number of active sites available for electrocatalytic reactions. In O 1s spectra, the three peaks at around 529.6, 531.2 and 533.0 eV are attributed to metal-oxygen, oxygen vacancies and surface adsorbed oxygen, respectively (Fig. S7c) [44]. Compared to the O 1s spectrum of CeO2, the proportion of metal-oxygen bonds is significantly increased, which may be due to the unsaturated coordination Co sites linking to Ce–O bonds in CeO2, forming the Co–O–Ce bridge at the heterointerface between Co and CeO2. And the peaks at around 780.2 and 795.7 eV in the XPS spectra of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs correspond to the metallic Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 peaks, respectively (Fig. 3b) [32,44]. Deconvolution of the Co 2p XPS spectra reveals three peak doublets for Co@NC, representing Co0, Co2+, and Co3+ peaks, accompanied by two satellite peaks [12,46]. The Ce 3d XPS spectra of CeO2@NC and H-Co/CeO2@NCBs reveal binding energies at around 882.4, 898.3, 901.1 and 917.2 eV in H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, corresponding to Ce4+ species, while peaks at around 885.2 and 903.3 eV are indicative of Ce3+ species, confirming the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in H-Co/CeO2@NCBs (Fig. 3c) [47,48]. Notably, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits similar characteristic peaks to Co@NC, with a slight positive shift of 0.2 eV in the center of Co 2p 3/2 peak, indicative of a decrease in electron density at the Co atom. Conversely, the Ce4+ peaks exhibit a negative shift of 0.2 eV compared to CeO2@NC. These findings indicate that the interfacial Co–O–Ce bridge established within the Co/CeO2 heterointerface promote electron transfer from Co to Ce sites via O atoms, thereby enhancing the catalyst's charge distribution. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis is utilized to gain insights into the local electron distribution of Co–O–Ce bridge and clarify its formation process. The Co K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) profile (red line) reveals the adsorption edge, indicating the energy absorption threshold of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs falls between Co and CoO (Fig. 3d). This suggests that the chemical valence of Co in the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs ranges from 0 to +2. The increased valence state of Co sites results from Co–O–Ce bridge at the heterointerface, facilitating charge/ion transfer in ORR/OER process and augmenting the inherent activity of the electrocatalyst [49]. Moreover, the Fourier-transformed (FT) extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data for H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits distinct peaks at around 1.7 and 2.2 Å, corresponding to the Co–O and Co–Co scattering paths, respectively (Fig. 3e and Table S1). The FT-EXAFS spectrum indicates that the presence of both Co–O and Co–Co in the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, confirming the coexistence of slightly oxidized Co species and Co nanoparticles (Fig. 3f). The Ce L-edge XANES spectra of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs closely resemble those of CeO2, showing a slight shift to the left and an increase in peak intensity (Fig. 3g). This suggests a reduction in the Ce oxidation state and a stronger interaction with the coordinated O atoms in its surrounding environment. CeO2 serves as an electron acceptor, linked through Co–O–Ce units that receive electron donation from Co, resulting in an elevated electron density in the Ce's 4f orbitals [50]. In the FT-EXAFS spectra of Ce L-edge, a significant contraction in the Ce–O bond lengths is observed, promoting covalent interactions that facilitate the efficient transfer of electrons along the Co–O–Ce bridge units (Fig. 3h, i and Table S2). Wavelet transforms (WT) clearly illustrate the variations in bond length (Ce–O) and coordination environment in H-Co/CeO2@NCBs (Fig. 3j–l). Thus, the combined analysis of XPS and XANES confirms the presence of interfacial Co–O–Ce bridge in H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, altering the catalyst's local electronic configuration and improving the adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. 2.3 ORR performance of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst To assess the ORR performances, the prepared catalysts (Co@NC, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, CeO2@NC, Co/CeO2@NC-1 and commercial Pt/C (20 wt.%)) are evaluated by using a three-electrode system in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The ORR activity of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is assessed through CV and LSV measurements (Fig. 4a, b ). H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits the highest positive reduction peak (0.89 V), which is higher than those of Co@NC (0.82 V), CeO2@NC (0.66 V), Co/CeO2@NC-1 (0.86 V) and Pt/C (0.87 V). The LSV curves exhibit that H-Co/CeO2@NCBs displays better half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.89 V) and onset potential (E onset = 1.08 V) than those of Co@NC (E 1/2 = 0.82 V, E onset = 0.96 V), CeO2@NC (E 1/2 = 0.66 V, E onset = 0.9 V), Co/CeO2@NC-1 (E 1/2 = 0.86 V, E onset = 1.05 V) and Pt/C catalysts (E 1/2 = 0.87 V, E onset = 1.01 V) (Fig. 4c). Additionally, in the Tafel plots, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits the smallest slope, indicating the fastest kinetic process, which is attributed to the Co/CeO2 heterointerface with the M-S effect (Fig. 4d). H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits the lowest charge transfer resistance, indicating the high efficiency of Co/CeO2 heterointerface for electron transport (Fig. 4e) [41]. The number of transferred electrons (n) in the ORR process for H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is determined through an ORR test involving adjustment of the rotational speed of the rotating disk (Fig. 4f). The calculated n values in the range of 0.3–0.6 V are approximately 4.0 (Fig. S8). The 4-electron oxygen reduction pathway of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is further validated through rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) testing, which yields an electron transfer number close to 4 and a H2O2 yield below 6.0 % (Fig. 4g and Fig. S9). The stability of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is assessed through chronoamperometry measurements (Fig. 4h). H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits outstanding stability, retaining 95.2% of its initial current after 24 h of continuous operation, surpassing other comparison samples. Additionally, the accelerated degradation test (ADT) indicates that the E 1/2 shift after 10,000 continuous CV cycles for H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is only 11 mV, which is significantly lower than Pt/C (23 mV) (Fig. 4i and Fig. S10). Simultaneously, post-mortem analyses of the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalysts reveal no significant changes in the structure and morphology after the ORR durability test, indicating that the structural robustness of the M-S heterointerface in alkaline electrolyte should contribute to the superior electrocatalytic stability of Co/CeO2 (Fig. S11). Moreover, the excellent stability is also ascribed to the fast electron pathway constructed by the M-S heterointerface, which possesses high intrinsic activity. 2.4 OER performance of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst In Fig. 5a, b, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits an excellent OER activity. H-Co/CeO2@NCBs has an overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is lower than those of the benchmark RuO2 (360 mV), Co@NC (390 mV), CeO2@NC (470 mV) and Co/CeO2@NC-1 (340 mV), demonstrating the beneficial impact of the M-S heterojunction on enhancing OER activity. Besides, the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits a better Tafel slope (54.8 mV dec−1) compared to other comparison samples. This improvement is attributed to the existence of the hybrid M-S structure, which enhances electronic properties and introduces additional active sites for OH− adsorption (Fig. 5c ) [33]. Based on the Nyquist plots, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs demonstrates a lower charge transfer resistance, indicating improved conductivity and accelerated reaction kinetic rate (Fig. 5d) [11]. The electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) values of Co@NC, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, CeO2@NC, Co/CeO2@NC-1 and RuO2 are estimated through CV tests at various scanning rates to establish their linear relationship with the ECSA (Figs. S12 and S13). H-Co/CeO2@NCBs shows the highest C dl value of 26.15 mF cm−2, indicating that it possesses the largest ECSA among the prepared catalysts, which is consistent with BET and LSV analyses (Fig. 5e). This is because the M-S heterointerface in the porous skeleton can provide more active sites due to the huge structural differences between the two phases. RRDE tests indicate the average n value of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is around 4.0, further validating 4e− OER mechanism (Fig. S14). Besides, the overpotential of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs shows a minimal negative shift of 14 mV after 10,000 cycles and it could work stably at 10 mA cm−2 for 24 h, demonstrating its outstanding durability (Fig. 5f). The H-Co/CeO2@NCBs of the stability test is characterized by XRD, SEM, and TEM, and it is found that the structure and morphology of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst does not change significantly after OER durability test (Fig. S15). In addition, the radar chart evaluates the performance of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs on five key parameters, clearly indicating that H-Co/CeO2@NCBs is an effective ORR/OER catalyst (Fig. 5g). Fig. S16 further verifies the remarkable ORR/OER bifunctional performance of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs, as demonstrated by the difference between OER and ORR potentials (ΔE = E j=10 − E 1/2). A smaller ΔE generally suggests a better bifunctional catalytic activity. The H-Co/CeO2@NCBs show a ΔE value of 0.65 V, which is significantly lower than those of advanced Pt + RuO2 couple and other comparison samples, and also outperforms a large number of recently reported nonprecious bifunctional electrocatalysts (Fig. 5h and Table S3). 2.5 DFT calculation It is evident that the spontaneous charge flow from Co to Ce atoms originates from the formative Co–O–Ce bridges, which facilitate continuous electron transport between the two phases. Partial density of states (PDOS) analysis indicates that heterojunction can markedly induce electronic delocalization compared to Co and CeO2 (Fig. 6a ). Besides, the Co/CeO2 possesses a d-band center closer to the Fermi level, suggesting a reduction in the electron arrangement of the antibonding orbitals, thereby enhancing the adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates, which is beneficial for both ORR and OER (Fig. 6b, c) [51–53]. To explore the synergistic effect of heterostructures in improving ORR/OER reaction pathways, all active sites for the adsorption of oxygen species (OOH*, O*, and OH*) are examined by calculating the Gibbs free energy for each step (Fig. 6d). The ORR free energy graph at U = 0 V shows Co, CeO2 and Co/CeO2 all possess downhill free energy pathways, which means that their ORR processes are thermodynamically favorable and spontaneous. At U = 1.23 V, the rate-determining step (RDS) of Co/CeO2 displays an energy barrier of 0.17 eV, which is lower than those of Co (0.24 eV) and CeO2 (0.41 eV), confirming an optimized adsorption state of oxygenate intermediates on Co/CeO2, thereby achieving the best ORR performance (Fig. 6e, g). The RDS of CeO2 involves formulating OH* from OH−, with the ΔG value being 1.88 eV during the OER process. Whereas, for Co and Co/CeO2 the RDS is the final step of deprotonation OH* to form O*, with ΔG values of 1.78 and 1.63 eV, respectively (Fig. 6f, g). The lower ΔG value of the RDS on Co/CeO2 further suggests enhanced OER electrocatalytic activity. The aforementioned results indicate that for the ORR process, the Co sites at the Co–O–Ce interface serve as the primary active centers, where electron-rich Co facilitates O2 adsorption and activation. In contrast, for the OER, the Co–O–Ce bridge itself acts as the dominant catalytic site, enabling efficient charge redistribution and stabilization of oxygenated intermediates through strong interfacial electronic coupling (Fig. 6h). 2.6 Liquid ZAB performance Considering the excellent ORR and OER performance of the bifunctional H-Co/CeO2@NCBs M-S electrocatalyst, a rechargeable liquid ZAB is fabricated using Zn foil as anode, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs as air cathode and 6 M KOH as electrolyte (Fig. 7a ). The open-circuit voltage (OCV) of the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based ZAB is 1.55 V (Fig. 7b), which is higher than those of Co@NC (1.43 V), CeO2@NC (1.38 V), Co/CeO2@NC-1 (1.51 V) and Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (1.49 V). In Fig. 7c, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based ZAB has a smaller charge/discharge voltage gap than those of Pt/C + RuO2-based battery, indicating its excellent reversibility. The H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based ZAB exhibits a larger maximum power density of 179.8 mW cm−2, which is markedly superior to Pt/C + RuO2 (128.8 mW cm−2) and other comparison samples (Fig. 7d). The galvanostatic discharge curves for the ZAB with H-Co/CeO2@NCBs cathode at various current densities (1–20 mA cm−2) show a smaller drop of voltage than Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (Fig. 7e). The ZAB with the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs exhibits high specific capacity of 805.9 mA h g−1, which is superior to Pt/C + RuO2 in Fig. 7f (705.3 mA h g−1). Moreover, galvanostatic discharge-charge tests are conducted to assess the cyclic stability of the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs cathode (Fig. 7g). The H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based ZAB exhibits exceptional cycling stability of 400 h with stable discharge/charge voltage, which is superior to Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (102 h). More importantly, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based ZAB exhibits minor changes in both the charge-discharge voltage gap (increase of 0.03 V) and energy efficiency (decline of 1.4 %) after 400 h of uninterrupted operation (Fig. 7h). Besides, the robust interaction between Co and CeO2 facilitates the generation of a steady heterointerface (Co–O–Ce), making H-Co/CeO2@NCBs suitable as a highly active catalyst. The performances including OCV, power density, specific capacity and durability, surpass numerous recently reported ZABs (Table S4). 2.7 Flexible ZAB performance To illustrate the application potential of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs as cathodic catalyst in wearable devices, self-assembled flexible all-solid-state ZAB (FZAB) is fabricated with PVA-KOH gel electrolyte and Zn foil anode (Fig. 8a ). Fig. 8b shows that H-Co/CeO2@NCBs based FZAB possesses a higher OCV of 1.43 V than Pt/C-RuO2 (1.32 V). The FZAB assembled with H-Co/CeO2@NCBs shows a reduced charge/discharge gap compared to Pt/C + RuO2, indicating its superior reversibility of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs (Fig. 8c). Furthermore, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs based FZAB exhibits a higher peak power density of 112.3 mW cm−2 than Pt/C + RuO2 (59.8 mW cm−2) (Fig. 8d). The charge-discharge voltage curves validate the promising stability of the FZAB across different bending conditions, indicating exceptional flexibility and stability (Fig. 8e). Furthermore, the FZAB featuring the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs cathode exhibits an impressive long-term cycling durability of 70 h, outperforming Pt + RuO2 and most recently reported bifunctional catalysts (Fig. 8f, g and Table S5). All the above-mentioned exciting results suggest promising potential for the application of H-Co/CeO2@NCBs in wearable devices. 3 Conclusions In summary, a straightforward MOF-assisted etching-pyrolysis strategy is developed to fabricate Co/CeO2 M-S heterostructure encapsulated in N-doped hollow carbon nanobox for bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis. The highly open hollow heterostructure endows the electrocatalyst with significantly exposed active sites and favorable mass transfer pathways. The formation of interfacial Co–O–Ce bridges facilitates the electronic modification of heterostructures through charge relocation, which is crucial for achieving superior catalytic performance. Additionally, Co–O–Ce bridges with Gibbs free energy modulation optimize the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates, thereby boosting the inherent ORR/OER activity of M-S heterostructure. Accordingly, the synthesized H-Co/CeO2@NCBs demonstrates superior ORR and OER performance, outperforming Pt/C and RuO2 standards and surpassing most previously documented Co-based catalysts. Furthermore, the liquid ZAB with the H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst demonstrates high power density (179.8 mW cm−2), energy efficiency (59.1 %), and operation durability (400 h) for practical application. H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-based FZAB also exhibits excellent flexibility and stability. This study introduces a new approach to guide the reasonable planning of ultra-efficient M-S heterostructure catalysts for promising energy storage and conversion and wearable electronics. coredata.dc:description: Designing a heterogeneous interface to improve the kinetics of electrocatalysts represents an effective yet challenging approach for enhancing the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, a simple MOF-assisted etching-pyrolysis strategy is proposed to fabricate an advanced Mott-Schottky (M-S) electrocatalyst composed of Co/CeO2 hetero-nanoparticles embedded within N-doped hollow carbon nanoboxes (H-Co/CeO2@NCBs). Notably, the interfacial Co–O–Ce bond bridging productively facilitates the electron transfer and modulates the charge distribution of the active center, thereby contributing to the ORR/OER kinetics. As expected, the optimal M-S H-Co/CeO2@NCBs catalyst exhibits promising bifunctional electrocatalytic activity with a small potential discrepancy of 0.65 V. Theoretical calculations reveal that the built-in electric field in the M-S heterojunction promotes electron transfer in oxygen electrocatalysis and the interfacial bridge-induced electron redistribution optimizes the adsorption/desorption of the oxygen intermediates, leading to reduced activation energy for the bifunctional ORR/OER reactions. Importantly, H-Co/CeO2@NCBs-assembled Zn-air battery (ZAB) delivers high power density (179.8 mW cm−2) and long-term stability (400 h). Furthermore, the assembled flexible solid-state ZAB with H-Co/CeO2@NCBs cathode also exhibits excellent charge-discharge reversibility and flexibility at various bending angles. This work provides a novel perspective on developing efficient and stable M-S bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts.
